Coton1at Trade We perceive, that many OF ous
cotempnra'ies, and oth.rs, are under the impres,
sion that Upper Canada is MI included n The bill
now before Congress in,erdicting all intercourse
with the British Colonies after the 5Oth of Septec,.
Der next A letter from Washington, published in
the New York Evening Post is sing ulariy in error
az to this fact 1t says" The intercourse will be
inetdc,ed after the s0lh September next, with all
the colonies except Upper Canada. The committee
did not positively decide The question as to Upper
Canada. but there is doubt the House will include
it," On referring TO the bill itself we find this
sweeping sentence, after mentioning by name the
colonies and places generally intended to be inclu-
ded IN the nerdclion, " or any other colony or pos
session, under the dominion of Great Britain in the
West Indies, or on the Continent Of .4merica's
This, we conceive, includes Upper Canada as efiec
tually as il it had been mentioned by name.

The U. $ Ship Hornet, Capt. .ateaander Cla1-
ton arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, in %
days passage from Vera Cruz, and proceeded di-
rectly up to the Navy Yard-officers and crew all
in good health, and having lost bu, 10y de-
bili,yl since she sailed from tho United States.


The Hornet discharged her pilot off the Della
ware Capes, On the Cd December, and arrived at
Vera Cruz on the Gath OF the same month. where
she landed Mr. Sergeant, Minister 70 the Congress
OF vacubays. who proceeded Immediately for the
City Of Me&ico She sailed from Vera Cruz on
the 9th inst. has had very boterous passage, and
been several dsys little to the Southwark of the
Cape.


Mr.. .KaSon Secretary Of the u. S. Legation to
the Mexican GoveInment--and bearer of Treaty
OF Ami,y and Commerce between the United States
and Mexico, recently concluded by MIR. Poinsett !;
and Mr.. Iolon, Mexican Consul, for Philadelphia,
came passengers in the Hornet.


The U. S. Ship John ADAMS, Capt. Wilkinson,
arrived at Vera Cruz a few days before the Hornet,
and sailed again for Tsmpico.


Two prizes to Com. Porter, had arrived at Vera
Cruz, one a valuable vessel and the other SLAYER
not of much value, the latter Of which he had cut
out from under the guns Of the Moro Castle. at
Havana Beacon.

The celebrated cause Of Christian Clarke vs.. tn,
Corporation Of the City OF Washington, is befor,
the Supreme Court Of the United States. Mr.
Clarke 1t will be recollected, few years ago, drew
a prize Of one hundred thousand dollars in the
Washington Lottery, the Manager Of which, d
Gillespie, absconded without paying the prizes
The great question involved in this suit is, the liza
billty OF the Corporation OF Washington for the
payment of the prizes. Counsel for the plaintiff
Messrs. WEBSTER, and Attorney General WRIT.
MIR. JONES is engaged on behalf Of the City. The
importance to both parties, Of the amount at stake
and the legal principles involved, ogs,her with the
fact that this has been decided in favor
OF the plaintiff, and at another time against him,
have contributed to render il one Of uncommon in
terest.


We learn from our last Washington papers, that
the argument in the above case was concluded on
Tuesday-and the decision was looked for with in.
tense anxiety by both parties

Capt. Alfred P. Edwards, passenger in the
Cham pion, which has arrived at Msrtha's Vineyard
states that while al the island OF Guam the capital
oil the Lsdrone islands, in April last, info maiion
was received tina, the island of Tnan had been Wis
tied by the British whale ship George the Fourth,
Captain Buckley, and that, after Teplenishing his
ship with refreshments, the captain commenced a
general devastation TIE island, by burning all the
houses built there, cutting down and destroying the
Bread Fruit, Cocoa Nu, Trees, Vines, &c. &c ard
left the island Two Of his crew. however, deserted
and were found in the island by the soldiers, anc
from them the facts we're confirmed. No reasons
were assigned for his conduct


The island Of Tinisn is he spot 10 which Lord
Anson, when on his voyage round the World. stop
ped for refreshment, when HI, crew was in the most
distressing situation, from the effects oil tho Scurvy
and the island is described by the writer Of Ansons
Voyage being of the most fertile and delight
ful spots on the face CT the Globe and from that
time it has been a iavorite stopping place for the
ships which visit the Pacific particularly the Anne
rican whale ships.


The Governor Of Guam had taken measures to
hare the houses rebuilt, and the fruit trees renewed

The celebrated cause Of Christian Clarke vs.. tn,
Corporation Of the City OF Washington, is befor,
the Supreme Court Of the United States. Mr.
Clarke 1t will be recollected, few years ago, drew
a prize Of one hundred thousand dollars in the
Washington Lottery, the Manager Of which, d
Gillespie, absconded without paying the prizes
The great question involved in this suit is, the liza
billty OF the Corporation OF Washington for the
payment of the prizes. Counsel for the plaintiff
Messrs. WEBSTER, and Attorney General WRIT.
MIR. JONES is engaged on behalf Of the City. The
importance to both parties, Of the amount at stake
and the legal principles involved, ogs,her with the
fact that this has been decided in favor
OF the plaintiff, and at another time against him,
have contributed to render il one Of uncommon in
terest.


We learn from our last Washington papers, that
the argument in the above case was concluded on
Tuesday-and the decision was looked for with in.
tense anxiety by both parties

Capt. Alfred P. Edwards, passenger in the
Cham pion, which has arrived at Msrtha's Vineyard
states that while al the island OF Guam the capital
oil the Lsdrone islands, in April last, info maiion
was received tina, the island of Tnan had been Wis
tied by the British whale ship George the Fourth,
Captain Buckley, and that, after Teplenishing his
ship with refreshments, the captain commenced a
general devastation TIE island, by burning all the
houses built there, cutting down and destroying the
Bread Fruit, Cocoa Nu, Trees, Vines, &c. &c ard
left the island Two Of his crew. however, deserted
and were found in the island by the soldiers, anc
from them the facts we're confirmed. No reasons
were assigned for his conduct


The island Of Tinisn is he spot 10 which Lord
Anson, when on his voyage round the World. stop
ped for refreshment, when HI, crew was in the most
distressing situation, from the effects oil tho Scurvy
and the island is described by the writer Of Ansons
Voyage being of the most fertile and delight
ful spots on the face CT the Globe and from that
time it has been a iavorite stopping place for the
ships which visit the Pacific particularly the Anne
rican whale ships.


The Governor Of Guam had taken measures to
hare the houses rebuilt, and the fruit trees renewed
